content:
Q: Can I continue my medical treatment for injury or sickness sustained overseas when I return to Singapore?
A: Yes, follow-up treatment in Singapore is covered within thirty (30) days after your return from the trip, provided that you have sought initial treatment overseas for Bodily Injury or Sickness during your trip and such initial treatment is claimable under Section 1 of the of the policy wording. If you have purchased our Pre-Existing Medical Conditions coverage add-on, please note that it only covers medical expenses incurred overseas and emergency medical evacuation. Follow-up treatment in Singapore for pre-existing medical conditions is not covered under this add-on.
questions: How does the policy define the coverage period and conditions for follow-up medical treatment in Singapore after an injury or sickness initially treated overseas during the trip?
What are the documentation or treatment prerequisites for claiming follow-up medical expenses in Singapore under Section 1 after an overseas injury or sickness?
In what ways does the Pre-Existing Medical Conditions coverage add-on limit coverage for medical expenses incurred overseas versus follow-up treatment in Singapore?
If a traveler sustains a pre-existing medical condition injury overseas, how does the policy differentiate coverage for initial overseas treatment and subsequent treatment upon return to Singapore?
What is the maximum time window allowed for follow-up treatment in Singapore to be claimable after returning from a trip with an initial overseas injury or sickness?
How does the policy handle claims for follow-up treatment in Singapore if the initial overseas treatment was not claimable under Section 1?
Can follow-up treatment in Singapore for injuries or sickness sustained overseas be claimed if the initial overseas treatment was not sought during the trip?
What exclusions or limitations apply to follow-up treatment in Singapore for pre-existing medical conditions under the Pre-Existing Medical Conditions add-on?
How does the policy treat emergency medical evacuation coverage in relation to pre-existing medical conditions and follow-up treatment?
If a traveler receives initial treatment overseas for a bodily injury covered under Section 1 but delays follow-up treatment in Singapore beyond 30 days, how does this affect claim eligibility?
Are there any differences in coverage for follow-up treatment in Singapore between injuries or sicknesses sustained from new conditions versus pre-existing conditions?
How does the policy wording clarify the interaction between Section 1 coverage and the Pre-Existing Medical Conditions add-on regarding overseas and Singapore-based medical expenses?
What conditions must be met for follow-up treatment in Singapore to be covered after a trip, and how do these conditions interact with the timing and location of initial treatment?
Does the policy require that the initial overseas treatment be successful or completed before follow-up treatment in Singapore can be claimed?
How does the policy address coverage for follow-up treatment in Singapore if the initial overseas treatment was for a condition excluded under general policy exclusions?
What are the implications for claimants if they seek follow-up treatment in Singapore for a sickness or injury that was not treated overseas during the trip?
How does the policy define 'initial treatment overseas' in the context of eligibility for follow-up treatment coverage in Singapore?
In cases where a traveler has purchased the Pre-Existing Medical Conditions add-on, how does the policy limit coverage for medical expenses incurred overseas versus those incurred in Singapore?
What documentation or proof might be required to demonstrate that initial treatment overseas was claimable under Section 1 to qualify for follow-up treatment coverage in Singapore?
How does the policy ensure that follow-up treatment coverage in Singapore is only applicable to injuries or sicknesses sustained and initially treated during the insured trip overseas?
